title: Schauspiel Frankfurt
text:
The Schauspiel Frankfurt is the municipal theatre company for plays in <a href="Frankfurt">Frankfurt</a>, <a href="Hesse">Hesse</a>, Germany. It is part of <a href="St%C3%A4dtische%20B%C3%BChnen%20Frankfurt">Städtische Bühnen Frankfurt</a>.
History.
In the late 1770s the theatre principal <a href="Abel%20Seyler">Abel Seyler</a> was based in Frankfurt, and established the city's theatrical life.
Opened in 1782, the "Comoedienhaus" (comedy house) was the first permanent venue of the Frankfurt theatre, both plays and opera (drama and opera). Its traditional house, the Schauspielhaus, build in 1902 by architect <a href="Heinrich%20Seeling">Heinrich Seeling</a> at the Theaterplatz (now <a href="Willy-Brandt-Platz">Willy-Brandt-Platz</a>) was destroyed in World War II. In 1926, Brecht's "<a href="A%20Respectable%20Wedding">A Respectable Wedding</a>" premiered.
Main temporary location of the Schauspiel from 1945 to 1963 was the Börsensaal. A new house for opera and play was built at the Theaterplatz, completed in 1963. When <a href="Harry%20Buckwitz">Harry Buckwitz</a> was general manager, the ruins of the Schauspielhaus were restructured to house both play and <a href="opera">opera</a>. Buckwitz focused on plays by Bertolt Brecht, including the world premiere of "<a href="The%20Visions%20of%20Simone%20Machard">Die Gesichte der Simone Machard</a>" in 1957.
On 31 October 1985, the planned first performance of Fassbinder's "Garbage, the City and Death" caused a theater scandal. Spectators occupied the stage and prevented the actors from continuing to play.
Städtische Bühnen.
Schauspiel Frankfurt is part of the municipal <a href="St%C3%A4dtische%20B%C3%BChnen%20Frankfurt">Städtische Bühnen Frankfurt</a>.
